qas.question: What is the purpose of a DBMS?

answers.text: to allow the definition, creation, querying, update, and administration of databases
according to the database model that they support

qas.question: What is the most popular DBMS?

plausible_answers.text: the definition, creation, querying, update, and administration of databases

qas.question: What is a DBMS designed to avoid?
What is generally portable across different DBMSs?
What is the least popular DBMS?
When did popular database systems stop releasing updates?

context: A <a0_0><b4_0>database management system<b4_0/><a0_0/> (DBMS) is a computer software application that interacts with the user, other applications, and the database itself to capture and analyze data. A general-purpose DBMS is designed <a1_0>to allow <b5_0>the definition, creation, querying, update, and administration of databases<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Well-known DBMSs include MySQL, PostgreSQL, Microsoft SQL Server, Oracle, Sybase, SAP HANA, and IBM DB2. A <b6_0>database<b6_0/> is not generally portable across different DBMSs, but different DBMS can interoperate by using standards such as SQL and ODBC or JDBC to allow a single application to work with more than one DBMS. Database management systems are often classified <a2_0>according to the database model that they support<a2_0/>; the most popular database systems since the <b8_0>1980s<b8_0/> have all supported the relational model as represented by the <a3_0><b7_0>SQL language<b7_0/><a3_0/>.[disputed – discuss] Sometimes a DBMS is loosely referred to as a 'database'.
